Summary In my PhD work, I modeled the sensing behavior of CNTFETs in the presence of oxidizing (NO_2) and reducing (NH_3) gases and determined how each of the transistor parameters, namely: the Schottky barrier height, Schottky barrier width and doping level of the nanotube are affected by the presence of these gases. I experimentally verified this by fabricating single channel back-gated carbon nanotube field effect transistors and exposing the devices to NO_2 and NH_3 gases in a custom built gas chamber. I experimentally verified this by fabricating single channel back-gated carbon nanotube field effect transistors and exposing the devices to NO_2 and NH_3 gases in a custom built gas chamber. Ultra High Dielectric Strength Biotronic Capacitors Based on Sol-Gel/DNA-CTMA Blends (Industrial project, TIPD,LLC)  
Developed biotronic capacitors based on organically modified sol-gel/DNA-CTMA blends.  
Devised sol-gel/DNA-CTMA/nanoparticle blends with superior performance exhibiting high dielectric constant. 
 
2. Solution Processed Colored Polarizer’s and Thin Films Exhibiting Polarized Emission 
Developed a method to align colored dichroic molecules in liquid crystal polymer films for polarizer applications. 
Synthesized photoluminescent dichroic molecules and fabricated their aligned films leading to polarized emission. PhD Graduate Student Rice University August 2005  –  November 2010  (5 years 4 months) Research Experience 
1. Dimension Controlled Self-assembly of Perylene Based Organic Semiconducting Molecule 
 Synthesized n-type perylene based organic semiconducting molecules having unique optical and electrical properties. 
 Designed solution processing methods for self-assembly of these molecules into highly ordered materials.  
 Demonstrated dimension controlled self-assembly (1D wires, 2D sheets and 3D crystals): by appropriate design of the perylene based molecules having various functional groups and controlling the conditions of self-assembly. 
 Developed materials open avenues to explore the structure-property-function relationships and their use in applications such as sensors, electronics and opto-electronic devices. 
 
2. Synthesis and 1D Self-assembly of Amphiphilic Gold and Silver Nanoparticles 
 Functionalized gold and silver nanoparticles covalently with amphiphilic polymers.  
 Self-assembled hybrid metal/polymer core-shell nanoparticles into 1D nanostructures by hydrophobic effect.  
 Self-assembled hybrid nanostructures hold potential for drug-delivery and catalysis based applications. 
 
3. Monodisperse Arrays Comprising Rings of the 1D Gold Nanorods  
 Synthesized 1D gold nanorods covalently functionalized with polystyrene and polybutadiene.  
 Self-assembled these anisotropic 1D gold nanorods into monodisperse uniform arrays of ring like superstructures.  
 Utilized various lithographic techniques and micro-contact printing to control the diameter of the rings of gold nanorods.  
 
4. Synthesis of Stable Iron Nanoparticles from Hemoglobin and Myoglobin 
 Devised method to synthesize air stable iron nanoparticles using biological precursors (Hemoglobin or Myoglobin)  
 Simplified the synthetic protocol in which the biological precursors act as source of iron, capping agents and also lead to narrow size distribution nanoparticles.
